questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with a 6-month history of photosensitivity, malar rash, and recurrent episodes of mucositis. He also reports headaches, seizures, and difficulty concentrating. Anti-nuclear antibody (ANA) testing is positive, and anti-dsDNA antibodies are present. A kidney biopsy reveals signs of lupus nephritis. A mutation analysis of which of the following genes is most likely to be informative, regarding the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) TREX1

 

Option C:

 

Mutations in the TREX1 gene, which encodes a DNAse enzyme, can lead to a monogenic form of SLE with early-onset disease and severe neuropsychiatric manifestations, as seen in this case. Mutations in TLR7, IRF5, and TNFSF4 can also increase the risk of SLE, but they are not typically associated with monogenic forms of the disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. TLR7: Gain-of-function mutations in TLR7 are associated with SLE, but they typically lead to adult-onset disease with a milder phenotype, not the early-onset and severe neuropsychiatric manifestations seen in this patient.

 

Option B. IRF5: Variants in IRF5 increase susceptibility to SLE, but they are not typically associated with monogenic forms or severe neuropsychiatric presentations.

 

Option D. TNFSF4: Mutations in TNFSF4 are linked to an increased risk of SLE, but they do not usually cause the specific combination of early-onset, neuropsychiatric symptoms, and lupus nephritis seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Monogenic lupus: A small percentage of SLE cases are caused by single gene mutations, with TREX1 being one of the most well-characterized. Patients with monogenic lupus often present with early-onset disease and may have more severe manifestations, including neuropsychiatric involvement. Identifying a TREX1 mutation can confirm the diagnosis of monogenic lupus and has implications for prognosis and treatment.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with pain, swelling, and tenderness in multiple joints, particularly her wrists and knees. She reports morning stiffness lasting about 30 minutes. Physical exam reveals warmth and tenderness in the affected joints, but no obvious deformities. On further question, patient used to experience photosensitive rash usually occurring over the cheeks. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) SLE-associated polyarthritis

 

Option D:

 

The patient's history of SLE, symmetrical involvement of multiple joints, and morning stiffness suggest SLE-associated polyarthritis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rheumatoid arthritis typically presents with more persistent morning stiffness and may cause joint erosions over time.

 

Option B. Osteoarthritis primarily affects weight-bearing joints and is characterized by bony enlargement and crepitus.

 

Option C. Psoriatic arthritis is often associated with skin psoriasis and typically involves the distal interphalangeal joints.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SLE-associated polyarthritis is a common manifestation of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), an autoimmune disease. It is important to recognize the clinical presentation of SLE-associated polyarthritis, which can include pain, swelling, and tenderness in multiple joints, along with other systemic symptoms like fatigue, fever, and rash.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a circular, erythematous lesion on her cheek with a raised, scaly border and a depigmented, atrophic center. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Discoid lupus erythematosus (DLE)

 

Option C:

 

The classic description of a DLE lesion is a round or oval erythematous plaque with a raised, scaly border and a central area of atrophy and scarring.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tinea corporis (Ringworm): While ringworm can present as a circular lesion, it typically has a more active, inflamed border and central clearing, often with itching. The description of depigmentation and atrophy doesn't fit this diagnosis.

 

Option B. Psoriasis: Psoriasis lesions are typically well-demarcated plaques with silvery scales, and they don't usually present with the same degree of central atrophy as seen in DLE.

 

Option D. Seborrheic dermatitis: This condition presents as greasy, yellowish scales and erythema, usually affecting areas rich in sebaceous glands like the scalp, eyebrows, and nasolabial folds. The depigmentation and atrophy seen in this patient are not characteristic of seborrheic dermatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing the characteristic features of DLE lesions is important for differentiating it from other skin conditions and initiating appropriate treatment.

questions.text: What is the approximate percentage of patients with DPGN who either die or develop ESRD within 10 years of diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 20%

 

Option C:

 

Approximately 20% of individuals with DPGN experience death or ESRD within 10 years, highlighting the need for aggressive treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DPGN is a severe form of lupus nephritis with a poor prognosis. Early recognition and aggressive treatment are essential to improve outcomes.

questions.text: A renal biopsy from a patient with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) shows diffuse mesangial hypercellularity with mesangial immune deposits on immunofluorescence. There is no evidence of glomerular crescents or endocapillary proliferation. This finding is consistent with which class of lupus nephritis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Class II

 

Class II lupus nephritis (mesangial proliferative LN) is characterized by mesangial hypercellularity and immune deposits, without significant endocapillary or extracapillary involvement.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Class I LN has normal glomeruli on light microscopy.

 

Option C. Class III LN involves focal segmental or global lesions.

 

Option D. Class IV-S(A) involves diffuse segmental proliferative lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classifying lupus nephritis is crucial for determining prognosis and guiding treatment decisions.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman with SLE presents with fatigue, dyspnea on exertion, and orthopnea. Physical examination reveals an S3 gallop, jugular venous distension, and bilateral lower extremity edema. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dilated cardiomyopathy

 

Option D:

 

The patient's presentation is consistent with heart failure, and dilated cardiomyopathy is a common cause of heart failure in SLE patients due to chronic myocarditis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pericardial effusion can cause similar symptoms, but the S3 gallop and bilateral edema are more suggestive of left ventricular dysfunction.

 

Option B. Mitral valve regurgitation can also cause heart failure, but it's less common in SLE.

 

Option C. Pulmonary hypertension can cause right heart failure, but the patient's symptoms and signs are more suggestive of left heart failure

 

Educational Objective:

 

SLE can affect the heart in various ways, including pericarditis, myocarditis, and valvular disease. Recognizing these cardiac manifestations is essential for early intervention and preventing complications.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with SLE presents with fatigue, pallor, and jaundice. Laboratory tests reveal anemia, elevated reticulocyte count, and a positive direct Coombs test. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) High-dose glucocorticoids

 

Option C:

 

The patient's presentation is consistent with autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA), a common hematologic manifestation of SLE. High-dose glucocorticoids are the first-line treatment for AIHA in SLE.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hydroxychloroquine is used for SLE management but not as the primary treatment for AIHA.

 

Option B. Rituximab is a second-line agent for refractory AIHA.

 

Option D. Platelet transfusion is not indicated for AIHA unless there is severe thrombocytopenia with bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

AIHA is a common hematologic manifestation of SLE and requires prompt treatment to prevent complications.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) presents with edema, fatigue, and foamy urine. Laboratory tests reveal proteinuria of 4.5 g/24 hours, hypoalbuminemia, and hyperlipidemia. What percentage of SLE patients with renal involvement typically develop nephrotic syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 25%

 

Option D:

 

  • Nephrotic syndrome is a clinical manifestation characterized by heavy proteinuria (>3.5 g/24 hours), hypoalbuminemia, edema, and hyperlipidemia.
  • In SLE, renal involvement is common, with 30-60% of patients experiencing proteinuria and cellular casts.
  • Of those with renal involvement, approximately 25% develop nephrotic syndrome, highlighting the importance of early detection and management of lupus nephritis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 5-10%: This is the percentage of SLE patients who develop end-stage renal disease, not nephrotic syndrome.

 

Option C. 30-60%: This is the percentage of SLE patients who develop renal involvement (proteinuria and cellular casts), not specifically nephrotic syndrome.

 

Option D. 80-90%: This is an overestimation of the prevalence of nephrotic syndrome in SLE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Renal involvement is common in SLE, and a subset of these patients will develop nephrotic syndrome. Early detection and management are crucial for preventing kidney damage.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man with a history of SLE for 10 years presents to the emergency department complaining of sudden, painless vision loss in his left eye. He denies any recent trauma, eye pain, redness, or light sensitivity. On examination, his vision is 20/200 in the left eye and normal in the right eye. Funduscopic examination of the left eye reveals cotton wool spots, retinal hemorrhages, and a pale optic disc. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Retinal vasculitis

 

Option D:

 

Retinal vasculitis can lead to retinal ischemia, hemorrhage, and scarring, resulting in significant vision loss.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Sicca syndrome: While common in SLE, it mainly causes dryness, irritation, and blurred vision, not sudden, painless vision loss.

 

Option B. Conjunctivitis: This is inflammation of the conjunctiva (the membrane lining the eyelids and covering the white part of the eye). It usually presents with redness, itching, tearing, and discharge, not sudden vision loss.

 

Option C. Episcleritis: This is inflammation of the episclera (the thin layer of tissue between the conjunctiva and the sclera, the white outer coating of the eye). It typically causes mild redness and discomfort, not sudden vision loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retinal vasculitis is a serious complication of SLE and requires urgent evaluation and treatment to preserve vision.

choices.text: Primary central nervous system (CNS) lymphoma

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) presents to the hospital with acute confusion, disorientation, and new-onset seizures. Brain MRI reveals multiple white matter hyperintensities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neuropsychiatric SLE (NPSLE)

 

Option B:

 

Neuropsychiatric SLE (NPSLE) is a common and potentially serious manifestation of SLE that can affect the central, peripheral, or autonomic nervous systems. The clinical presentation of NPSLE is diverse and can include cognitive dysfunction, mood disorders, psychosis, seizures, and headache. White matter hyperintensities on MRI are a characteristic finding in NPSLE.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Primary central nervous system (CNS) lymphoma: While CNS lymphoma can occur in SLE patients, it is less common than NPSLE and typically presents with focal lesions rather than diffuse white matter hyperintensities.

 

Option C. Multiple sclerosis: Multiple sclerosis can also present with white matter lesions on MRI, but the clinical history of SLE and other systemic symptoms makes it less likely in this case.

 

Option D. Cerebral vasculitis: Cerebral vasculitis is a possible complication of SLE, but it usually presents with focal neurological deficits and less commonly with diffuse cognitive impairment. Additionally, MRI findings in cerebral vasculitis often show ischemic lesions rather than predominantly white matter hyperintensities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NPSLE is a common and potentially debilitating manifestation of SLE. Early recognition and treatment are essential to prevent long-term neurological damage.

questions.text: A 37-year-old female presents with a 6-month history of joint pain, photosensitive rash, and intermittent oral ulcers. Laboratory investigations were ordered to assess for autoimmune disorders. An Antinuclear Antibody (ANA) test was performed using indirect immunofluorescence on HEp-2 cells. The result is shown in the image below. Based on the pattern observed, which of the following conditions is most likely associated with this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)

 

Option A:


The image shows a homogenous (diffuse) nuclear staining pattern, which is commonly associated with SLE. This pattern is characterized by uniform staining of the entire nucleus, often linked to antibodies against dsDNA and histones, which are frequently seen in SLE patients.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA): RA may show a positive ANA with different patterns, but the homogeneous pattern is not as strongly associated with RA as it is with SLE.
 

Option C. Scleroderma: Scleroderma ANA patterns often include nucleolar, centromere, or speckled patterns, not typically homogenous.
 

Option D. Sjögren's Syndrome: Sjögren's Syndrome is more commonly associated with a speckled ANA pattern and anti-SSA/Ro and anti-SSB/La antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing the homogeneous pattern in ANA testing is important, as it strongly suggests the possibility of SLE. However, further testing, including specific antibody tests and clinical evaluation, is necessary for a definitive diagnosis.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man is evaluated for symptoms of arthritis, fatigue, and an intermittent rash. Considering his clinical presentation, an Antinuclear Antibody (ANA) test is performed, and the results show a distinct immunofluorescence pattern, shown below. Which autoimmune disease is most closely associated with this ANA pattern?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)

 

Option B:


The 'rim' or 'peripheral' pattern in ANA immunofluorescence is characteristic of antibodies against double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) and is most closely associated with Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE). This pattern shows concentrated fluorescence at the edges of the nucleus, indicative of the specific autoantibodies found in SLE.

 

Explanation:


Option A. Rheumatoid Arthritis is typically associated with rheumatoid factor and anti-CCP antibodies, not the 'rim' ANA pattern.
 

Option C. Sjögren's Syndrome is more commonly associated with anti-Ro/SSA and anti-La/SSB antibodies, which can produce a different ANA pattern.
 

Option D. Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma) often shows ANA patterns such as the nucleolar pattern, not the 'rim' pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identifying the rim pattern in ANA testing is a valuable clue for diagnosing SLE. It signifies the presence of specific autoantibodies targeting dsDNA, a hallmark of the disease. However, it's important to remember that not all SLE patients will exhibit this pattern, and further diagnostic workup is necessary.

choices.text: No new lupus disease activity compared to the previous visit

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a criterion for defining Lupus Low Disease Activity State (LLDAS)?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anti-double-stranded DNA antibody titer < 1:80

 

Option D:

 

While anti-dsDNA antibody titers can be helpful in monitoring SLE activity, they are not part of the formal LLDAS criteria.

 

Explanation:

 

 

The other options (A, B, and C) are all essential criteria for LLDAS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

LLDAS is a state of low disease activity in SLE, defined by specific criteria including a SLEDAI-2K score ≤ 4, no new disease activity compared to the previous visit, and a physician's global assessment ≤ 1 (scale 0-3). Understanding these criteria is essential for monitoring disease activity and adjusting treatment plans in SLE patients.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with severe lupus nephritis is scheduled to begin treatment with high-dose cyclophosphamide. She is concerned about the potential side effects of this medication, particularly the risk of ovarian failure. Which of the following medications can be used to reduce this risk?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Leuprolide

 

Option C:

 

Leuprolide, a gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist, can be co-administered with cyclophosphamide to protect ovarian function by suppressing ovulation.

 

Explanation:

 

The other options do not protect against cyclophosphamide-induced ovarian failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cyclophosphamide is a potent immunosuppressive agent used in severe lupus nephritis, but it can cause premature ovarian failure. Co-administration of leuprolide can mitigate this risk and preserve fertility in young women.

questions.text: A young woman with SLE presents with new confusion, seizures, and shortness of breath. Exam shows fever, rash, and fluid overload. Labs reveal worsening kidney function and blood counts. Urine analysis suggests nephrotic range proteinuria. Biopsy confirms class IV lupus nephritis. What is the typical initial dose of glucocorticoids?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 0.5-1 mg/kg per day

 

Option B:

 

The typical initial dose of prednisone or equivalent for severe SLE is 0.5-1 mg/kg per day. Higher doses may be used in certain situations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

High-dose glucocorticoids are the cornerstone of initial therapy for severe SLE manifestations due to their rapid anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects. However, their use should be balanced with the risk of side effects and tapered as soon as possible.

questions.text: A patient with SLE has a renal biopsy showing diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (DPGN) classified as ISN/RPS Class IV. Which of the following is the most appropriate induction therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glucocorticoids + cyclophosphamide

 

Option D:

 

Class IV lupus nephritis is a severe form requiring aggressive induction therapy. The combination of glucocorticoids and cyclophosphamide has been shown to be effective in reducing progression to ESRD and death.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hydroxychloroquine alone: Hydroxychloroquine is used for milder SLE manifestations.

 

Option B. Low-dose prednisone alone: Low-dose prednisone is insufficient for severe nephritis.

 

Option C. Mycophenolate mofetil (MMF) alone: MMF can be used but is not the standard of care for induction in Class IV LN.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Class IV lupus nephritis is the most severe form of lupus nephritis and requires aggressive induction therapy. The combination of glucocorticoids and cyclophosphamide is the standard of care for induction, followed by maintenance therapy with mycophenolate mofetil or azathioprine.

questions.text: A 55-year-old Caucasian man presents with fatigue, arthralgia, myalgia, and a low-grade fever. He has been taking hydralazine for hypertension for the past six months. Blood investigations showed Positive ANA. Given the likely diagnosis, which of the following antibodies will be present in this patient, in high titres?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anti-histone antibodies

 

Option D:

 

The patient's clinical presentation, along with the positive ANA test and history of hydralazine use, strongly suggest a diagnosis of Drug-Induced Lupus Erythematosus (DILE). Anti-histone antibodies are highly specific (nearly 100%) for DILE, although they are not always present in every case.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Anti-dsDNA antibodies: These are more specific for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and are less likely to be elevated in DILE.

 

Option B. Anti-Smith antibodies: While present in SLE, anti-Smith antibodies are not usually elevated in DILE.

 

Option C. Anti-Ro/SSA antibodies: These antibodies are associated with both SLE and Sjögren's syndrome but are not a hallmark of DILE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing the association between anti-histone antibodies and DILE is crucial for accurate diagnosis. This is especially important when a patient presents with lupus-like symptoms while taking a medication known to trigger DILE.

choices.text: The patient has a high risk of developing systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
The patient is likely to have permanent organ damage.
The patient is expected to have complete resolution of symptoms upon drug withdrawal.
The patient will require lifelong immunosuppressive therapy.

questions.text: A patient with DILE induced by hydralazine has been successfully treated. Which of the following statements regarding prognosis is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The patient is expected to have complete resolution of symptoms upon drug withdrawal.

 

Option C:

 

DILE typically resolves within weeks to months after discontinuation of the offending drug, and long-term sequelae are rare.

 

Explanation:

 

The risk of developing SLE is not increased after DILE. Permanent organ damage and lifelong immunosuppression are not usually necessary for DILE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The prognosis of DILE is generally good, especially with prompt recognition and discontinuation of the offending drug. Patients should be reassured that their symptoms are likely to resolve and long-term complications are rare. However, monitoring for recurrence of symptoms is important if the drug is reintroduced.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a 5-year history of Raynaud's phenomenon presents with progressive skin thickening that is limited to his fingers, hands, and face. He also reports occasional episodes of facial and hand swelling. He offers no other complaints. Physical examination reveals sclerodactyly, telangiectasias on the face, and puffy fingers. Pulmonary function tests and echocardiogram are normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc)

 

Option A:

 

  • Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc) is characterized by skin thickening that is limited to the distal extremities (fingers, hands) and face. It is also associated with prominent vascular manifestations like Raynaud's phenomenon and telangiectasias. Internal organ involvement is less common and tends to occur later in the disease course compared to diffuse cutaneous SSc.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis (dcSSc): This subtype involves skin thickening that extends proximal to the wrists and affects the trunk. Internal organ involvement is more common and occurs earlier in dcSSc compared to lcSSc.

 

Option C.  Scleroderma sine scleroderma: This rare variant of SSc is characterized by Raynaud's phenomenon and internal organ involvement without significant skin thickening.

 

Option D. Overlap syndrome: This refers to a combination of SSc with features of other connective tissue diseases like polymyositis, dermatomyositis, or systemic lupus erythematosus. There is no evidence of overlap in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing the distinct clinical features of lcSSc is essential for accurate diagnosis and appropriate management.

questions.text: Which of the following antibodies is considered an SSc-specific autoantibody?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anti-topoisomerase I (Scl-70) antibody

 

Option C:

 

Anti-topoisomerase I (Scl-70) is a specific autoantibody found in patients with SSc.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Anti-nuclear antibody (ANA): ANA is not specific to SSc and can be found in other autoimmune diseases.

 

Option B. Anti-double stranded DNA (anti-dsDNA) antibody: Anti-dsDNA is specific for SLE.

 

Option D. Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibody: Anti-CCP is specific for rheumatoid arthritis

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identifying SSc-specific autoantibodies like anti-Scl-70 can aid in diagnosis, subtype classification, and prognostication in patients with suspected SSc.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with Raynaud's phenomenon and progressive skin thickening of her hands. Which of the following haplotypes is most strongly associated with an increased risk of systemic sclerosis (SSc)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HLA-DRB111:04

 

Option C:

 

HLA-DRB111:04, along with DQA105:01 and DQB1*03:01, forms a haplotype that has been consistently identified as a major risk factor for SSc in various populations.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. HLA-DRB104:01 is associated with rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Option B. HLA-DRB107:01 and Option D. HLA-DRB115:01 have not been consistently linked to SSc.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the genetic predisposition to SSc can help identify individuals at higher risk and potentially contribute to the development of targeted preventive strategies.

questions.text: A patient with suspected systemic sclerosis presents with a speckled pattern on antinuclear antibody (ANA) testing. Which autoantibody is most likely associated with this pattern and carries an increased risk of scleroderma renal crisis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anti-RNA polymerase III antibody

 

Option C:

 

A speckled ANA pattern is commonly associated with anti-RNA polymerase III antibodies in SSc. This antibody is linked to an increased risk of developing scleroderma renal crisis, a serious complication characterized by sudden onset of malignant hypertension and acute kidney injury.

 

Explanation:

 

Option ACA: Centromere pattern, limited SSc, lower renal crisis risk.

 

Option Scl-70: Nucleolar/speckled nucleolar pattern, diffuse SSc, lower renal crisis risk.

 

Option Anti-U3-RNP: Nucleolar pattern, overlap syndromes, less common in SSc, lower renal crisis risk

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing the association between the speckled ANA pattern, anti-RNA polymerase III antibodies, and scleroderma renal crisis is crucial for early detection and prompt intervention to prevent renal failure.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a 3-year history of Raynaud's phenomenon and new onset skin tightening of the fingers. Which of the following investigations is MOST helpful in differentiating between primary Raynaud's disease and limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nailfold capillaroscopy

 

Option C:

 

Nailfold capillaroscopy allows direct visualization of microvascular changes in the nailfold capillaries, which are characteristic of SSc (e.g., enlarged, dilated, or absent capillaries). In primary Raynaud's disease, the nailfold capillaries are typically normal.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Antinuclear antibody (ANA) test: ANA testing can be positive in both conditions but is not specific for differentiation.

 

Option B. Pulmonary function tests (PFTs) and Option D. Echocardiogram assess for internal organ involvement, which is more common in later stages of SSc and not helpful in early differentiation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nailfold capillaroscopy is a valuable tool in the early diagnosis of SSc, particularly in patients presenting with Raynaud's phenomenon. It can detect microvascular abnormalities before the onset of significant skin changes or internal organ involvement.

questions.text: Which of the following medications has shown promising results in recent clinical trials for slowing the progression of SSc-associated interstitial lung disease (SSc-ILD)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nintedanib

 

Option C:

 

Recent clinical trials have demonstrated that nintedanib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, can significantly slow down the decline in lung function in patients with SSc-ILD. It can be used alone or in combination with mycophenolate mofetil.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. D-penicillamine has not shown consistent benefits in recent controlled trials for SSc-ILD.

 

Option B. Mycophenolate mofetil is often used in SSc, but its primary role is in treating skin and other organ involvement, not specifically ILD.

 

Option D. Cyclophosphamide is a potent immunosuppressant used for severe SSc manifestations, but it's not the first-line treatment for ILD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nintedanib is an emerging treatment option for SSc-ILD, offering potential hope for patients with this debilitating complication of SSc.

choices.text: PAH is a rare complication of SSc.
PAH is typically symptomatic early in its course.
PAH accounts ~30% of deaths in SSc.
The prognosis of PAH in SSc is generally favorable.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) in systemic sclerosis (SSc) is TRUE?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PAH accounts ~30% of deaths in SSc.

 

Option C:

 

PAH is a devastating complication of SSc and is a leading cause of death in these patients, contributing to approximately 30% of mortality.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. PAH is a rare complication of SSc: PAH is not rare in SSc; it occurs in a significant minority of patients.

 

Option B. PAH is typically symptomatic early in its course: PAH is often asymptomatic until advanced stages, making early detection crucial.

 

Option D. The prognosis of PAH in SSc is generally favorable: The prognosis of PAH in SSc is poor without treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PAH is a common and serious complication of SSc. Recognizing the symptoms and initiating appropriate treatment can improve outcomes and prolong survival.

questions.text: A patient with scleroderma renal crisis (SRC) is found to have activation of the complement pathway on renal biopsy. Which of the following medications might be considered as an adjunct to ACE inhibitor therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Eculizumab

 

Option B:

 

Eculizumab, a monoclonal antibody that inhibits the complement pathway, has shown promise in some studies as an adjunct therapy for SRC, particularly in cases with evidence of complement activation.

 

Explanation:

 

  • The other medications are not specifically targeted towards complement inhibition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eculizumab is a novel therapeutic option for SRC that targets the underlying pathophysiology of the disease. Further research is needed to determine its long-term efficacy and safety in this setting.

choices.text: Neutrophilic infiltration of exocrine glands
Lymphocytic infiltration of exocrine glands
Deposition of immune complexes in blood vessels

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with complaints of dry mouth, dry eyes, and fatigue. On examination, you note enlarged parotid glands and dental caries. Given the likely diagnosis, which of the following is the characteristic histopathological findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lymphocytic infiltration of exocrine glands

 

Option C:

 

Sjögren's syndrome is defined by lymphocytic infiltration of the exocrine glands, particularly the salivary and lacrimal glands.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Granulomatous inflammation: Granulomatous inflammation is seen in sarcoidosis.

 

Option B. Neutrophilic infiltration of exocrine glands: Neutrophilic infiltration is characteristic of acute infections.

 

Option D. Deposition of immune complexes in blood vessels: Immune complex deposition is seen in vasculitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing the characteristic histopathological findings in Sjögren's syndrome is crucial for confirming the diagnosis. A lip biopsy is commonly performed to assess the minor salivary glands for lymphocytic infiltration.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female is diagnosed with primary Sjögren Syndrome after presenting with dry mouth, difficulty swallowing, and bilateral parotid gland enlargement. Which of the following tests is most specific for diagnosing primary Sjögren Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anti-Ro/SSA and Anti-La/SSB antibodies

 

Option C:


Anti-Ro/SSA and Anti-La/SSB antibodies are highly specific for Sjögren Syndrome and are key serological markers in its diagnosis. Their presence, particularly in patients with typical clinical features of the syndrome, such as dry mouth (xerostomia), dry eyes (keratoconjunctivitis sicca), and glandular enlargement, strongly supports the diagnosis of primary Sjögren Syndrome.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rheumatoid factor (RF) can be positive in Sjögren Syndrome but is not specific as it can be positive in other autoimmune diseases, including rheumatoid arthritis.
 

Option B. Anti-nuclear antibody (ANA) can be positive in a wide range of autoimmune diseases and is not specific to Sjögren Syndrome.
 

Option D. Anti-smooth muscle antibody (ASMA) is associated with autoimmune hepatitis and not specific for Sjögren Syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While other tests like RF and ANA can be positive in Sjögren's syndrome, they are not as specific as anti-Ro/SSA and anti-La/SSB antibodies. These antibodies, in combination with clinical features, are crucial for establishing the diagnosis of primary Sjögren's syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is the MOST common extraglandular manifestation in primary Sjögren's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arthralgias/Arthritis

 

Option B:

 

The table shows that arthralgias/arthritis occur in 60% of primary Sjögren's syndrome patients, making it the most common extraglandular manifestation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fatigue (25%),

 

Option C. Raynaud's phenomenon (37%),

 

Option D. lung involvement (14%) are less common.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing the wide range of extraglandular manifestations in Sjögren's syndrome is important for comprehensive patient care. While the primary symptoms involve dryness of the eyes and mouth, other organs can be affected, with arthralgias/arthritis being the most prevalent.

questions.text: A patient with Sjögren's syndrome presents with palpable purpura on the lower extremities, arthralgia, and peripheral neuropathy. Which of the following is the most likely underlying pathophysiology?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cryoglobulinemia-associated vasculitis

 

Option A:

 

The combination of purpura, arthralgia, and neuropathy in a Sjögren's patient strongly suggests cryoglobulinemia-associated vasculitis, a type III hypersensitivity reaction.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. T-cell mediated cytotoxicity: T-cell mediated cytotoxicity is involved in other autoimmune diseases but not the primary mechanism in this scenario.

 

Option C. Anti-Ro/SSA antibody-mediated damage: Anti-Ro/SSA antibodies are associated with Sjögren's but don't directly cause vasculitis.

 

Option D. Granulomatous inflammation: Granulomatous inflammation is more characteristic of conditions like sarcoidosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cryoglobulinemia-associated vasculitis is a serious complication of Sjögren's syndrome. Recognizing the associated symptoms and understanding the underlying pathophysiology is crucial for timely diagnosis and appropriate management.

questions.text: Which of the following autoantibodies is associated with an increased risk of multiple myeloma in Sjögren's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anti-Ro52 antibodies

 

Option D:

 

Recent studies have shown that Sjögren's syndrome patients with anti-Ro52, anti-Ro60, or anti-La autoantibodies have an increased risk of developing multiple myeloma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While the exact mechanism linking anti-Ro52 antibodies to multiple myeloma is not fully understood, this association highlights the importance of monitoring Sjögren's patients with these antibodies for potential hematological malignancies.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of well-controlled hypertension on medication presents with worsening Raynaud's phenomenon over the past few months. He recently started taking a new medication for migraine prophylaxis. Which medication is most likely to be contributing to his worsening Raynaud's?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Beta blocker

 

Option C:

 

Beta blockers: These medications are known to worsen Raynaud's phenomenon due to their vasoconstrictive effects. They reduce blood flow to the extremities, which can exacerbate the symptoms of Raynaud's.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Calcium channel blockers: These are often used to treat Raynaud's phenomenon because they promote vasodilation and improve blood flow to the extremities.

 

Option B. Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors: These medications can also help improve blood flow, but they are not as commonly used for Raynaud's as calcium channel blockers.

 

Option D. Statins: Statins are used to lower cholesterol and are not known to worsen Raynaud's phenomenon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

It is crucial to consider the potential impact of medications on Raynaud's phenomenon when managing patients with this condition. Beta blockers should be used with caution or avoided in individuals with Raynaud's, and alternative medications may need to be considered.

choices.text: Order an antinuclear antibody (ANA) test and rheumatoid factor

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a 2-year history of episodic color changes in her fingers when exposed to cold temperatures. The episodes start with blanching, followed by cyanosis, and then redness as her fingers rewarm. Physical examination reveals the changes shown in the picture. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in differentiating primary from secondary raynaud’s?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Perform nailfold capillaroscopy

 

Option C:

 

Nailfold capillaroscopy is a non-invasive test that allows visualization of the microvasculature at the base of the fingernails. It is a valuable tool for differentiating primary Raynaud's phenomenon (vasospastic disorder) from secondary Raynaud's phenomenon associated with connective tissue diseases like scleroderma. In primary Raynaud's, the capillary pattern is usually normal, while in secondary Raynaud's, it often shows abnormalities like capillary dropout, dilation, and microhemorrhages.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Reassurance and observation: While primary Raynaud's phenomenon is generally benign, it's crucial to rule out secondary causes, especially in patients with new-onset symptoms or those with additional features suggestive of a connective tissue disease.

 

Option B. Initiate treatment with nifedipine: Nifedipine, a calcium channel blocker, can be helpful in managing Raynaud's phenomenon, but it's important to establish the diagnosis first.

 

Option D. Order an antinuclear antibody (ANA) test and rheumatoid factor: These tests can help identify underlying autoimmune diseases, but nailfold capillaroscopy is a more specific and sensitive test for differentiating primary and secondary Raynaud's phenomenon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nailfold capillaroscopy is a valuable diagnostic tool for distinguishing primary and secondary Raynaud's phenomenon. Early differentiation is essential for identifying and managing any underlying connective tissue disease that may be causing the secondary Raynaud's.

questions.text: A patient with Raynaud's phenomenon presents with severe digital ischemia and necrosis of the fingertips. Which of the following medications is most likely to be considered for treatment in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Iloprost

 

Option B:

 

Iloprost, a prostacyclin analog, is a potent vasodilator and can be used in severe cases of Raynaud's with digital ischemia.

 

Explanation:

 

Nifedipine, losartan, and sildenafil are used in milder cases or as preventive measures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize that severe Raynaud's phenomenon requires aggressive treatment with potent vasodilators like iloprost to prevent tissue loss and improve outcomes.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with secondary Raynaud's phenomenon due to systemic sclerosis experiences severe episodes of digital ischemia, leading to fingertip ulcers. His condition has not improved with calcium channel blockers. Which of the following therapeutic options is most appropriate for managing his severe condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endothelin receptor antagonists

 

Option B:

 

Endothelin receptor antagonists (ERAs): These medications, such as bosentan and ambrisentan, are vasodilators specifically targeting the endothelin pathway. They are approved for the treatment of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) and have shown efficacy in improving blood flow and reducing digital ulcers in patients with severe Raynaud's phenomenon

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Thermal biofeedback: This non-pharmacological therapy can be helpful in mild to moderate Raynaud's, but it is unlikely to be sufficient for severe cases with digital ulcers.

 

Option C. Topical nitroglycerin ointment: This medication is primarily used to improve local blood flow and may be beneficial in milder cases of Raynaud's, but its efficacy in severe cases with ulcers is limited.

 

Option D. Cyclophosphamide: Cyclophosphamide is an immunosuppressant used for severe manifestations of systemic sclerosis, but it is not the first-line treatment for Raynaud's phenomenon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand that ERAs are effective in treating severe Raynaud's phenomenon, especially in the context of systemic sclerosis. They target the endothelin pathway, which plays a key role in vasoconstriction and vascular remodelling.
